ns0:r.ns0:t: for AI Agent Orchestration, Task Execution & Memory
This Obsidian vault serves as the central nervous system for

‚Äî an AI orchestration platform that manages tasks, automations, and knowledge. Each folder in the vault maps to a functional region of the human brain, creating an intuitive architecture for how information flows, gets processed, stored, and acted upon.

The vault is designed so that both humans and AI agents can navigate it naturally. Folders are numbered (000‚Äì130) to maintain consistent sort order across file browsers, CLI tools, and agent file access.

The system is split into two distinct locations with different responsibilities. The Obsidian Vault is the brain ‚Äî it remembers, tracks, and documents rules and processes. The Projects folder is the body ‚Äî it holds the actual work product, source code, and project-specific documentation that gets pushed to GitHub.

Mixing orchestration files with source code creates problems: git merge conflicts when agents update task status, Obsidian indexing thousands of code files it doesn‚Äôt need, bloated vaults, and agents accidentally editing source code when they should be updating notes. The separation keeps each system clean and purpose-built.

An Obsidian vault is ideal for OpenVault because it‚Äôs just folders of plain-text Markdown (.md). That makes the ‚Äúbrain‚Äù portable, searchable, and easy to version, while keeping automation safe and predictable for agents.

Using the Obsidian CLI (or scripted vault operations) saves energy by reducing context switching: you can capture and append notes, move files, and batch-update metadata from the terminal and automations without opening the app. Humans still get a high-touch experience through the GUI‚Äîcustom dashboards and home pages, backlink navigation, and curated views‚Äîbuilt on the same simple file types.
Source code, project docs, configs, local files, GitHub repos
Each project is its own GitHub repo
Reads for HOW to work (skills, prompts, routines, rules)
Reads for WHAT to work on (code, docs, issues, phases)
CLAUDE.md and docs/ provide project-specific context

The only project file inside the Obsidian Vault is tasks.md ‚Äî one per active project. This single file is the nerve that connects brain to body. It contains task status, priority, assignee, due dates, and GitHub issue links. Just enough for the Dashboard to aggregate across all projects, but no project-specific documentation.
Raw captures, unsorted notes, clippings before processing
Central routing, system status, daily briefing
Immediate task tracking: today, upcoming, someday
Agent configs, logs, templates, and memory
Procedural memory: reusable skills and commands
Higher reasoning: system prompts, chains, fragments
Cross-linking, maps of content, tag indexes
Episodic recording: daily, weekly, decisions, agent runs
Replicable patterns for all vault content types
Just as the brain receives raw sensory data from the eyes, ears, and skin before routing it to specialized regions, the Inbox captures all unprocessed input before it gets organized.

This is the default landing zone for anything captured quickly ‚Äî ideas, links, screenshots, voice memos, clippings from the web, or quick notes you jot down on the go. Nothing lives here permanently; it gets triaged into the appropriate folder during regular processing.
Process the Inbox at least once daily (or set up an agent to auto-triage)
Keep items here less than 48 hours
Use the routing-rules.md in 015-Dashboard to define where items should go
The prefrontal cortex handles planning, decision-making, and executive function ‚Äî the highest-order thinking. This is where complex, multi-step initiatives are managed.
Each project gets its own subfolder under Active, On-Hold, or Completed. Projects contain everything needed to execute: an overview, task lists, phase breakdowns, logs, and reference materials.
Project summary: goals, scope, stakeholders, timeline
Project-specific task list with status tracking
Project-specific activity logs and meeting notes
Supporting docs, links, specs relevant to this project
The thalamus acts as the brain‚Äôs central relay station, routing sensory information to the correct cortical regions for processing. The Dashboard serves the same role for the vault.
This is the nerve center of the vault. It provides at-a-glance system status, tells
what to focus on, generates daily briefings, and defines the rules for how Inbox items get routed to the right folders.
Health status of all automations, agents, backups, and
should prioritize RIGHT NOW ‚Äî the current directive
Auto-generated morning summary: tasks due, alerts, calendar, priorities
Rules defining how Inbox items get auto-sorted into folders
Working memory in the prefrontal cortex holds the items you‚Äôre actively thinking about ‚Äî typically 4‚Äì7 items at a time. This folder is the vault‚Äôs immediate task register.
Unlike 010-Projects (which are large, multi-phase efforts), Tasks are individual action items that need to be done. The tasks.md file uses the
task tracker format with status emojis, timestamps, and agent attribution.
Tasks that must be completed today
Tasks scheduled for the near future (this week / next week)
Ideas and tasks with no firm deadline ‚Äî the backlog
The RAS filters thousands of incoming signals and decides what deserves conscious attention. It‚Äôs why you notice your name in a crowded room. The Watchlist defines what
This folder holds everything that needs passive monitoring. Rather than requiring active work, these items trigger attention only when specific conditions are met.
Active alert conditions and thresholds (e.g., price drops below $X, HRV below Y)
Things being tracked: stock prices, health metrics, project deadlines, uptimes
RSS feeds, API endpoints, data streams, and webhooks to watch

Neural pathways are the brain‚Äôs wiring ‚Äî established routes that carry signals between regions. Agents are the vault‚Äôs active processes: defined, configured, and capable of independent execution.

This folder defines WHO does the work. Each agent has a configuration, produces logs, and can draw on persistent memory. The Memory subfolder uses a brain-inspired split between working, episodic, and semantic memory.
Agent definitions: system prompts, personas, tool access, capabilities
Agent run history: what they did, when, and results
Reusable agent templates for spinning up new agents quickly
Current session context and scratchpads ‚Äî clears regularly
Records of specific events and interactions over time
Consolidated facts, learned patterns, permanent knowledge
The amygdala tags experiences with emotional weight so the brain knows what deserves immediate attention versus what can wait. The Priorities folder does the same for tasks and projects.
This is the vault‚Äôs triage system. Agents can auto-classify items using the rules defined in priority-rules.md, and humans can override at any time.
üî¥ Must act immediately ‚Äî blockers, failures, urgent deadlines
üü† This week ‚Äî important but not emergency
üü° Scheduled and on track ‚Äî proceeding as planned
üü¢ Backlog ‚Äî nice to have, no deadline pressure
Rules for how agents should auto-classify urgency levels
The cerebellum stores procedural memory ‚Äî learned patterns like riding a bike or typing. Once learned, they execute automatically. Skills are the vault‚Äôs reusable capabilities.
Skills define WHAT agents can do. They‚Äôre reusable, composable, and can be shared across agents and tools. The skill-index.md acts as a manifest so agents can discover available capabilities.
Reusable slash commands and code snippets for Claude Code
Pre/post hooks and event handlers for Claude Code workflows
Skills usable across any agent or tool ‚Äî platform-agnostic
Registry of all available skills with descriptions and status
Synapses are the junctions between neurons where signals pass from one to another. MCP (Model Context Protocol) is the communication layer that connects agents to external tools and data sources.

This folder holds the configuration for all MCP servers, custom tool definitions, resources, and prompt templates that agents can access. The mcp-registry.md provides a single pane of glass for everything connected.
MCP server configs and connection details (filesystem, GitHub, Obsidian, etc.)
Custom tool definitions exposed via MCP to agents
MCP resource definitions ‚Äî data sources agents can read
MCP prompt templates served to connected clients
Master index of all MCP servers, their tools, and capabilities
The neocortex handles abstract thinking, language, reasoning, and synthesis ‚Äî the most sophisticated cognitive functions. Prompts are the instructions that direct this higher-order processing.

Separated from agent configs because prompts are composable and reusable across agents. Chains define multi-step workflows, and Fragments are mix-and-match pieces that can be assembled into larger prompts.
System prompts and CLAUDE.md files that define agent behavior
Reusable task-specific prompts (e.g., summarize, analyze, generate)
Multi-step prompt chains and workflows (research ‚Üí summarize ‚Üí file)
Composable prompt snippets and partials for assembly

The autonomic nervous system controls automatic bodily functions: heartbeat, breathing, digestion. You never think about them, but they‚Äôre always running. Routines are the vault‚Äôs background processes.
This folder is split into conscious (scheduled, triggered) and unconscious (autonomic) processes, mirroring the brain‚Äôs separation of voluntary and involuntary actions.
Always-on processes that never need attention: backups, syncs, heartbeats, health checks
Cron jobs and weekly tasks ‚Äî you set them, they execute on a timer
Event-driven rules: when X happens, do Y (e.g.,
Multi-step orchestrated workflows that chain multiple actions
Manual routines and SOPs: daily standup, weekly review, monthly audit
The temporal lobe processes and stores long-term reference information including language and patterns. Bookmarks store curated external references organized by type.
Software, SaaS products, CLIs, and utilities you use or want to try
Saved articles, blog posts, and long-form reads worth keeping
GitHub repositories and open-source projects of interest
How-to guides, courses, and learning resources
Frequently visited documentation sites and reference portals
Long-term memories are stored distributed across the neocortex ‚Äî organized by domain. This is the vault‚Äôs permanent knowledge base, organized by subject area.
Unlike Bookmarks (external links), Knowledge contains your own notes, calculations, strategies, and accumulated expertise. This is what agents reference when they need domain-specific context.
Strategies, setups, portfolio notes, market analysis
HRV insights, sleep data analysis, fitness protocols, wellness tracking

The corpus callosum is the massive fiber bundle connecting the brain‚Äôs two hemispheres, enabling cross-communication. Without it, the left hand literally doesn‚Äôt know what the right is doing. Connections prevent vault silos.
This is the meta-layer that links knowledge across domains. It prevents folders from becoming isolated islands and enables agents to discover relationships between projects, skills, and knowledge.
Master index (MOC) linking related notes across the entire vault
Canonical tags used across the vault with definitions
What depends on what: projects ‚Üî skills ‚Üî agents ‚Üî MCP servers
Explicit link files connecting items across domains
The prefrontal cortex doesn‚Äôt just plan ‚Äî it also maintains your sense of identity, social rules, and contextual awareness. The Context folder shapes HOW agents behave in different situations.
CLAUDE.md files for different projects and repos
Role definitions: ‚Äúact as PM,‚Äù ‚Äúact as trader,‚Äù ‚Äúact as engineer‚Äù
Working memory for active agent sessions ‚Äî temporary, disposable
The hippocampus converts experiences into memories, recording what happened, when, and in what context. Logs are the vault‚Äôs episodic memory system.
Everything that happens gets recorded here. Daily journals, weekly reviews, decision records, and agent execution logs. This creates an audit trail and enables agents to learn from past actions.
Daily journal entries and standup notes
Decision records with context, options considered, and rationale
Timestamped logs of agent executions: what ran, when, and output
DNA provides the replicable blueprints for building biological structures. Templates are the vault‚Äôs blueprints ‚Äî standardized patterns that ensure consistency when creating new content.
Standard structure for new project folders
Format for individual task entries with status tracking
Daily journal template with sections for wins, blockers, and focus
Standard format for defining a new agent
Template for documenting a new skill
Template for registering a new MCP server connection

The brain compresses and consolidates rarely-accessed memories, making them harder to retrieve but still preserved. The Archive stores retired content that‚Äôs no longer active but may be useful someday.
Move completed projects, outdated configs, and deprecated skills here rather than deleting them. Agents can still search the Archive when historical context is needed.
How Information Flows Through the Vault
Understanding the flow of information through the vault is critical for both human users and AI agents. Here‚Äôs the typical lifecycle:
New information enters through 000-Inbox ‚Äî a quick note, a clipped article, an agent output, or a captured idea.
The 015-Dashboard/routing-rules.md determines where the item goes.
agents can auto-triage, or you process manually.
Items get tagged with urgency in 035-Priorities. Critical items bubble up to active-focus.md in the Dashboard.
Tasks in 020-Tasks get worked using Skills from 040-Skills, executed by Agents from 030-Agents, following Routines from 070-Routines.
The 025-Watchlist passively monitors conditions and triggers alerts when thresholds are crossed.
Everything that happens gets logged in 110-Logs ‚Äî creating the episodic memory that agents and humans can review.
Insights, learnings, and knowledge extracted from logs and projects get consolidated into 090-Knowledge for permanent storage.
The 095-Connections folder maintains relationships across all domains, preventing information silos and enabling discovery.
Completed projects and outdated content move to 130-Archive, preserved but out of the active workspace.
Each project under ~/Projects/ is its own GitHub repository. This is where
stores local files, tracks issues and tasks within the codebase, and manages phase-specific work. All source code, project documentation, configs, and assets live here ‚Äî never in the vault.
Source code, application logic, components, scripts
Project-specific activity logs and change history
Project-specific agent context and coding instructions
Template for environment variables (no real values)
Standard GitHub readme for the repository
Every project has a docs/ folder that contains the context
needs to understand the work. When an agent picks up a task from the vault, it navigates here first.
Project summary: goals, scope, stakeholders, timeline, and current status
How data flows through the system, what triggers what, architecture diagrams
Tools, APIs, platforms, and third-party services used in the project
Database schemas, API endpoints, data sources, and data flow
Environment variable names and vault paths ‚Äî never actual credentials
reads the vault‚Äôs 015-Dashboard for active focus, then scans 010-Projects/Active/ to find which projects have tasks ready. It reads skills, prompts, and routines to understand how to operate.
Using the Local and Docs paths stored in tasks.md,
navigates to ~/Projects/{{name}}/ and reads docs/overview.md, docs/workflow.md, and CLAUDE.md to understand the project context.
or Claude Code operates on the source files in ~/Projects/{{name}}/
/, using the vault‚Äôs skills and prompts for guidance. All code changes happen in the Projects folder, never in the vault.
updates tasks.md in the vault with status changes, timestamps, and GitHub links. It logs the run in 110-Logs/Agent-Runs/, and the Dashboard auto-aggregates the new state across all projects.
Code changes in ~/Projects/{{name}}/ get committed and pushed to GitHub. The vault‚Äôs tasks.md links to the relevant issues and PRs so everything stays connected and traceable.

Each project uses a unique 2‚Äì3 letter prefix so task IDs are globally unique across the vault. When a task appears in the Dashboard or today view, the prefix tells you immediately which project it belongs to.

The Obsidian Vault is the brain: it remembers what needs to be done, how to do it, and what happened. The Projects folder is the body: it holds the actual work product, source code, and project context. The tasks.md file is the nerve that connects them.
reads both to operate effectively ‚Äî the vault for strategy and memory, the project folder for execution and context.

Every project follows a six-phase lifecycle. Phases provide structure for how work progresses from idea to production, and every task is tagged with the phase it belongs to. This creates a clear picture of where a project stands at any moment ‚Äî both at the individual task level and as an overall progress bar.
These phases are standard across all projects. Each phase has a short code used in task tables, and a gate ‚Äî criteria that must be met before the project advances to the next phase.
Goals defined, feasibility confirmed, resources identified, competitor analysis complete
Wireframes approved, UI/UX finalized, prototype reviewed and accepted
Core features built, backend and frontend integrated, APIs connected, code reviewed
All critical bugs fixed, performance acceptable, security audit passed, cross-device testing complete
Live on production, monitoring active, rollback plan ready, users can access
Ongoing ‚Äî no exit gate. Monitor performance, fix bugs, release updates

Phases are overlapping, not rigid sequential. Tasks from future phases can be created and queued while the current phase is active. However, future-phase tasks must stay in Queued status until their phase activates. This is practical for real projects ‚Äî you can plan QA tasks during development without waiting for dev to finish completely.
Tasks in the current phase can be Queued, In Progress, or Completed
Tasks in future phases must remain Queued until that phase activates
Tasks in past phases should be Completed or moved to Blocked/Failed
A phase activates when the previous phase‚Äôs gate criteria are met
Phase definition files live in the Projects folder (the body), not the vault. Each project has a docs/phases/ directory with one file per phase.
reads these to understand objectives, deliverables, and gate criteria for each phase.
Phase directory inside the project repo
Goals, feasibility, competitor analysis, resource needs
Wireframes, prototypes, UI/UX decisions, design specs
Architecture, tech stack, feature breakdown, API design
Test plan, test cases, device matrix, performance targets
Deploy steps, environments, rollback plan, monitoring setup
Bug triage process, update schedule, monitoring alerts
Each phase file in the Projects folder follows this standard structure:
Gate Criteria: specific, measurable conditions to advance
What this phase aims to accomplish. Written as clear goals that agents can reference when picking up tasks tagged with this phase.
Concrete outputs with checkboxes. Each deliverable links to a task ID from tasks.md so agents can track which deliverables map to which tasks.
What must be complete before this phase can proceed. References prior phase outputs, external approvals, third-party access, or other project dependencies.
Technical decisions, tool choices, architecture notes, and any context that helps agents execute tasks within this phase effectively.
The tasks.md file is the single bridge between the Obsidian Vault and the Projects folder. One exists per active project, located at 010-Projects/Active/{{
}}/tasks.md inside the vault. This section defines the exact format for both humans and
The top of every tasks.md contains metadata that tells
where to find the project and what state it‚Äôs in:
GitHub repository URL with clickable link
Local filesystem path to the project (~/Projects/{{name}})
Set to Build or Ops so dashboards and automations know whether this task set drives product work or operations.
2‚Äì3 letter project prefix for globally unique task IDs
Active phase with emoji indicator (e.g., üîµ 3 ‚Äî Development)
Visual progress bar showing all six phases (e.g., ‚úÖ‚úÖüîµ‚¨ú‚¨ú‚¨ú)
The main table where all in-flight work is tracked. Each row is a single task with full metadata:
Globally unique: project prefix + sequential number (e.g., ST-001)
Short, actionable description of the work
Phase code the task belongs to (1-Plan, 2-Design, 3-Dev, 4-QA, 5-Deploy, 6-Maint)
Emoji status: üü° Queued, üîµ In Progress, ‚úÖ Completed, ‚ùå Failed, ‚è∏Ô∏è Paused, üö´ Blocked
Emoji priority: üî¥ Critical, üü† High, üü° Normal, üü¢ Low
Target completion date (YYYY-MM-DD or shorthand M/DD)
Link to GitHub issue or PR (e.g., #12 linked to full URL)
Short context, blockers, progress notes, or dependency references
When a task finishes, it moves from Active to Completed. This table adds a Completed date and Duration column to track velocity.
ID, Task, Completed (date), Duration (time spent), GitHub link, Notes
Tasks that cannot proceed due to a dependency are tracked separately so they‚Äôre visible at a glance.
ID, Task, Blocked By (dependency task ID), Since (date), Notes
Here is a complete example showing the updated format with separate Build and Ops tables:
| ID | Task | Phase | Status | Priority | Assignee | Due | GitHub |
| {{PX}}-001 | Build alert API | 3-Dev | üîµ In Progress | üü† High |
| ID | Task | Category | Status | Priority | Assignee | Due | GitHub |
| {{PX}}-050 | Fix null pointer in parser | üêõ Bug | üîµ In Progress | üü† High |
| {{PX}}-052 | Add rate limiting | üîí Security | üü° Queued | üü† High | ‚Äî | 2/19 | #16 |
| ID | Task | Type | Completed | Duration | GitHub | Notes |
| {{PX}}-000 | Scaffold project repo | Build | 2026-02-12 | 2h | #1 | Initial setup |

tests| Build | {{PX}}-001 | 2026-02-15 | Needs API schema finalized |
The vault‚Äôs 015-Dashboard/daily-brief.md auto-aggregates phase status across all active projects, giving you a single view of where everything stands:
Every tasks.md includes hidden HTML comments at the bottom that tell

exactly how to operate. These instructions cover where to look for project context, where to look for operational knowledge, and the step-by-step rules for updating task status, creating GitHub issues, and logging runs. Agents parse these comments before making any changes.

Not every task follows a six-phase lifecycle. There is a real difference between building a new trading alert system (multi-phase, weeks of work, sequential dependencies) and fixing a login bug (do it, close it, move on). Forcing one-off tasks through six phases creates unnecessary overhead. The system recognizes two distinct task types.

Follow the six-phase lifecycle. These are features, new systems, or major changes that require planning through deployment. They have phases, dependencies, deliverables, and gate criteria. Build tasks are the structured work that moves a project forward through its phases.

Single-action items with no phase progression. Bug fixes, config changes, dependency updates, quick improvements, investigations. They get created, worked, and closed. Ops tasks keep the project healthy without advancing its phase.
Single action, hours to a day
No phase ‚Äî tagged with a category (Bug, Security, etc.)
Often blocked by other tasks or phases
Maps to phase objectives and milestones
The fix or change IS the deliverable
Instead of phases, ops tasks use a category that describes the nature of the work. This lets the Dashboard filter and group ops tasks by type.
Dependency updates, library upgrades, version bumps
Vulnerability patches, auth fixes, hardening, audit items
Performance improvements, optimization, caching, query tuning
Environment changes, settings, infrastructure tweaks, env vars
Documentation updates, README, inline comments, API docs
Research, debugging, root cause analysis, feasibility checks
Refactoring, cleanup, tech debt, code hygiene
To keep build and ops tasks visually distinct within the same tasks.md file, use separate ID number ranges. This way when you see a task ID, you immediately know its type without checking the table.
The tasks.md file now has separate tables for Build and Ops tasks. Build tasks use the Phase column, Ops tasks use the Category column. Both share the same status and priority systems.
| ID | Task | Phase | Status | Priority | Assignee | Due | GitHub |
| {{PX}}-001 | Build alert API | 3-Dev | üîµ In Progress | üü† High |
| ID | Task | Category | Status | Priority | Assignee | Due | GitHub |
| {{PX}}-050 | Fix null pointer in parser | üêõ Bug | üîµ In Progress | üü† High |
| {{PX}}-052 | Add rate limiting | üîí Security | üü° Queued | üü† High | ‚Äî | 2/19 | #16 |
The daily brief now shows both build progress (phases) and ops health (active issues) for each project, giving a complete picture of where things stand:

Build tasks drive the project forward through phases. Ops tasks keep the project healthy. Both live in the same tasks.md file but in separate tables, with distinct ID ranges and their own classification system (phases for build, categories for ops). The Dashboard aggregates both types so you always have the full picture.
This log tracks all revisions to the
Initial release. 18-folder brain-mapped vault architecture, information flow lifecycle, folder reference guide.
Added Brain vs Body architecture section. Separated Obsidian Vault (brain) from Projects folder (body). Defined tasks.md as the bridge. Added project folder layout and docs/ structure.
Added Phases & Task Management section. Six-phase lifecycle (Planning through Maintenance) with codes, gate criteria, overlap rules, phase file templates, and full tasks.md specification.

Added architecture diagram (Brain vs Body visual). Added Build Tasks vs Ops Tasks section with categories, ID numbering convention, and dashboard aggregation. Removed GitHub box from architecture diagram.
). Updated title page, headers, and diagram. Replaced example tasks.md with updated Build + Ops split format including Type column in Completed/Blocked tables. Added revision log.
